M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, "[u]pon a complaint after a divorce, the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parties as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require."

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Where the parties are not or were not married, an identical standard applies under M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, empowering the Court to modify custody and parenting time “as the best interests of the child may require” upon a material change in circumstances.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad authority under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 to tailor parenting-time provisions to protect the minor child’s welfare and to ensure that arrangements remain reasonable and workable in light of changed circumstances.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Father’s relocation and the resulting change in the practical effect of the midweek overnight constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss relocation, midweek overnights, or how a move changing the practical effect of parenting-time constitutes a material and substantial change. The only material and substantial change identified is the mother’s rehabilitation from alcohol and drug dependence. The case is about whether separating twins between parents was in their best interests, not about relocation as a basis for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … In allowing the wife's complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife's ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Father’s relocation and the resulting change in the practical effect of the midweek overnight constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion is about an unmarried mother who moved out of state before paternity was established, and it holds that the judge had no authority to order her and the child back or to treat the move as subject to a removal/relocation analysis. It does not address what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances” for modification purposes, nor does it treat the father’s relocation or the practical impact on midweek overnights as such a change. Instead, it emphasizes that, as sole legal parent, the mother was free to relocate and that distance is only relevant to fashioning visitation, not as a basis to disturb her move.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. ... Seen in light of the mother’s legitimate New York residence and the provisions of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), the distance separating the parties had relevance only as a factor in devising a reasonable long-distance visitation order."

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The existing parenting-time schedule is no longer in the child’s best interests and must be modified to reflect the realities of Father’s relocation and the child’s evolving needs.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, not a generic modification of parenting-time to reflect a relocating parent and evolving child needs. The SJC affirms denial of the mother’s requested relocation and maintains the existing shared custody arrangement; it does not state that an existing parenting-time schedule is no longer in the child’s best interests and must be modified when a parent relocates. While it discusses best interests and effects of relocation, its holding is that the current arrangement should continue, not that it must be modified to reflect relocation realities.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court. … The judge determined that the father’s move to Nashua did not provide ground for the relief requested by the mother, and the judge did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The existing parenting-time schedule is no longer in the child’s best interests and must be modified to reflect the realities of Father’s relocation and the child’s evolving needs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is about an initial custody determination and the interaction between the best-interests standard and statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a); it is not a modification case based on a parent’s later relocation or a child’s evolving needs. The opinion expressly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ modification standard under § 20 and does not discuss modifying an existing parenting-time schedule due to relocation realities. Thus, it does not provide authority for modifying a parenting schedule in response to a later move or changed needs, as the proposition states.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: The controlling standard for any custody or parenting-time determination is the “best interests of the child.”
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection/custody case and repeatedly frames the inquiry in terms of the children’s welfare, speaking of their ‘best interest’ and the need for a ‘stable and safe environment.’ While the decision is more focused on the clear-and-convincing ‘current unfitness’ standard for permanent removal, the court expressly recognizes that custody decisions turn on whether committing the children to the department is in their best interest. Thus, it is reasonably good authority for the best-interests standard as the controlling consideration in custody/parenting-time determinations, though not in a generalized way for all types of custody disputes.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding. … The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 511\u.proposition: To modify a prior custody or parenting-time order, the moving party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order; and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 511\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support orders, not custody or parenting time. It expressly distinguishes the statutory standard for modifying child support (an inconsistency with the Child Support Guidelines) from the material and substantial change standard, which it notes applies to custody modifications under the first paragraph of G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not itself set out or apply the two-part custody/parenting-time standard described in the proposition. Thus, this case is not proper authority for that specific proposition, even though it references the history of § 28.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 511\u.relevant_excerpt: "The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders. Compare § 28, first par., fourth sentence (after divorce, on complaint, court may modify prior judgment as to ‘the care and custody of the minor children’ on finding that occurrence of a ‘material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties’ and best interests of children make modification necessary), with § 28, first par., fifth sentence ..."

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: To modify a prior custody or parenting-time order, the moving party must show: (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order; and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the standards for an initial custody determination in a divorce judgment, emphasizing that the governing principle is the welfare/best interests of the child and that the judge must weigh all relevant factors. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor does it articulate any requirement to show a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore it does not support the specific two‑part modification standard in the claimed proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.raw_text: Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326 (2007)
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that significant changes in a parent’s residence, the feasibility of the existing schedule, or the impact of existing arrangements on a child’s schooling and well-being can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision and does not frame the issue as whether there has been a material change in circumstances warranting modification. The court discusses the Yannas/Mason "real advantage" and best-interest standards for relocation, quality of life of the custodial parent, in camera interviews, and recording requirements; it does not hold that changes in residence, feasibility of the schedule, or impact on schooling constitute a "material change" for modification purposes. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific material-change proposition stated.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.relevant_excerpt: "In cases such as the one before us, the ‘real advantage’ test applies. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 705, 706, 711 (1985) (parents had ‘joint legal custody,’ but mother had ‘physical custody’). ... Under the real advantage test, ‘[s]hould it be found that there is a genuine, recognizable advantage to the custodial parent from the move, the inquiry then turns to whether the move is consistent with the children’s best interests.’"

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that significant changes in a parent’s residence, the feasibility of the existing schedule, or the impact of existing arrangements on a child’s schooling and well-being can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case is an initial divorce and custody/removal judgment, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. The opinion applies the ‘real advantage’ standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 to decide whether the custodial parent may relocate, but it does not discuss ‘material change in circumstances’ or modification standards, nor does it address altering an existing schedule due to changes in residence, schooling, or well-being. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about material change justifying modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243–44 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: In determining a child’s best interests, courts consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the child’s stability, the effect of proposed arrangements on the child’s emotional, physical, and educational welfare, and each parent’s capacity to meet those needs.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that custody determinations under c. 209C are made based on the child’s best interests and that the judge may consider any factors pertinent to those interests. In applying that standard, the opinion discusses the child’s age-appropriate development, need for stimulation and enrichment (developmental and educational needs), stability and structure in each home, the impact on the child’s emotional and physical welfare, and each parent’s capacity and judgment in meeting those needs. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition about the range of best-interests factors courts consider.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute. … In addition to assessing the quality of the care provided by the primary caretaker, and the various factors specified in § 10(a) … a judge is to identify and weigh those factors pertinent to the child’s best interests. Here, the judge’s voluminous findings demonstrate consideration of myriad factors and circumstances relevant to the child’s best interests….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: In determining a child’s best interests, courts consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the child’s stability, the effect of proposed arrangements on the child’s emotional, physical, and educational welfare, and each parent’s capacity to meet those needs.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child when making custody determinations. While it discusses the impact of witnessing violence on a child’s development and mentions the child’s preference and school progress, it does not set out a broader, structured list of best-interest factors such as age, developmental needs, stability, overall emotional/physical/educational welfare, and each parent’s general capacity to meet those needs. The case is thus narrower than the multifactor proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ ... It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. ... There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence, especially during important developmental stages."

Villiers v. Villiers, 448 Mass. 1007 (20.proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that continuity in schooling, preservation of a stable routine, and adequate rest are central components of a child’s best interests.
Villiers v. Villiers, 448 Mass. 1007 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion is an attorney discipline case about mishandling client funds and the appropriate sanction. It does not involve family law, custody, or any discussion of children’s best interests, schooling, routines, or rest. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about continuity in schooling and stable routines being central to a child’s best interests.
Villiers v. Villiers, 448 Mass. 1007 (20.relevant_excerpt: In reviewing the disciplinary sanction imposed by a single justice, we “inquire whether the judgment is markedly disparate from those ordinarily entered by the various single justices in similar cases.” Matter of Jackman, 444 Mass. 1013, 1013 (2005), quoting Matter of Alter, 389 Mass. 153, 156 (1983). Nonetheless, “[e]ach case must be decided on its own merits and every offending attorney must receive the disposition most appropriate in the circumstances.” Three Attorneys, supra at 837.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The Court has broad authority under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 to tailor parenting-time provisions to protect the minor child’s welfare and to ensure that arrangements remain reasonable and workable in light of changed circumstances.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case focused on G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas real‑advantage test, not on the court’s general modification authority under c. 208, § 28 or c. 215, § 6. While the panel briefly quotes c. 208, § 28 to correct the trial judge’s view of “changed circumstances,” it does not discuss or articulate any broad power to tailor or adjust parenting‑time provisions or to ensure workability in light of future changes. The case therefore does not provide authority for the broad proposition about parenting‑time tailoring under §§ 28 and 215, § 6.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”}
